Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigating the Characteristics of Lower Tropospheric Airborne GPS Radio Occultation Observations and Their Impact in Hurricane Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Summary
The hurricane genesis process is known to depend on the degree of vertical instability needed to support deep convection and on mid-level moistening, which modulates convective activity. However, the time variation of moistening is poorly known due to the lack of high temporal and spatial observations during the genesis process. Global Positioning System (GPS) Radio Occultation (RO) provides area-averaged profiles of refractivity (which depends on moisture and temperature) with very high vertical resolutions that are complementary to dropsondes (pointwise, high vertical resolution) and satellite retrievals (high horizontal but poor vertical resolution). GPS RO is insensitive to heavy precipitation, clouds, and winds. Since the Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate (COSMIC) became operational, space borne GPS RO data have shown a positive impact on global numerical weather prediction models in the mid to upper troposphere range. However, the use of the data at lower levels has lagged for several reasons: 1) complications due to strong horizontal variations in moisture 2) difficulties in signal tracking and 3) sparse observations within the window of interest for mesoscale systems. This has led to minimal impact in tropical cyclone genesis and forecasting, and minimal impact below mid-troposphere in general. Airborne RO can play a major role in advancing understanding of the hurricane genesis process, because dense targeted measurements are simpler to make with an airborne system than with the existing space borne constellation.

The PIs will take advantage of a unique opportunity to collect data during the Pre-Depression Investigation of Cloud Systems of the Tropics (PREDICT) campaign in August 2010, which will allow them to test their progress in data assimilation for the case of tropical cyclone genesis. The data assimilation results should be of great interest to PREDICT investigators because they will provide better initial conditions for high-resolution models for testing new hypotheses concerning the evolution of tropical disturbances into hurricanes.

Broader Impacts: The project will promote the use of airborne radio occultation to an expanded research community and serve as a feasibility test for hurricane hunter surveillance missions, potentially resulting in a direct societal benefit from improved operational forecasts. This research activity will educate graduate students and promote the advancement of postdoctoral researchers within an international collaborative structure between Taiwan and US universities. It will strengthen research programs led by four female investigators, who will serve as role models for their students as well as other young female scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lack observations of high vertical resolution atmospheric thermodynamic structure (temperature and moisture) inside or near the hurricane limits the understanding of hurricane genesis processes, which leads to the limited predicting capability of hurricane track and intensity in numerical weather prediction models. The side-looking airborne GPS radio occultation (ARO) technique offers dense sampling of the atmospheric thermodynamic structure inside and near the storms without the need to flight into the dangerous storm center. However the ARO retrieval system based on the geometric-optics (GO) theory produce poor quality soundings in the moist lower troposphere (e.g., below 5 km) due to the complex signal dynamic resulting from the large moisture variations.  

The primary goal of the project (AGS-1262041) is to develop a new airborne radio occultation (ARO) retrieval algorithm based on wave-optics (WO) theory, which significantly improves the quality of ARO observation in the moist lower troposphere. This is in line with the overarching goal of the collaborative research project, i.e., to improve understanding of the hurricane genesis by providing high-resolution atmospheric thermodynamic structure through airborne GPS RO soundings near the hurricane.  

In this project, the PI leads the development of an ARO retrieval algorithm based on the wave-optics (or radio-holographic) method. More specifically the full-spectrum-inversion (FSI) algorithm is developed and tested to resolve the multipath problem of ARO measurements in the moist lower troposphere. The multipath problem results in significant errors in both airborne and spaceborne RO retrievals that are based on geometric-optic method.  The FSI retrieval has been successfully applied by spaceborne RO community but will be applied on the airborne RO sounding for the first time with the advantage of achieving much higher vertical resolution without being restrained by the diffraction-limited coarse resolution as seen in the geometric-optics method. End-to-end simulation study demonstrate the capability of the FSI method to retrieve fine atmospheric vertical structure in the moist lower troposphere, where geometric-optic (GO) retrieval method fails due to the presence of atmospheric multipath.

The simulation study also revealed that both FSI and GO inversion methods introduce bending angle errors near the receiver height, which lead to >1% refractivity error near the receiver height but decreasing quickly downward at lower altitudes. The bending angle error near the receiver height can be easily corrected with the aid of the in-situ refractivity measurement. The missing correction of the large bending errors will result in significant bias in ARO refractivity retrieval. The FSI retrieval also showed a weaker sensitivity to signal amplitude errors as compared to the refractivity errors at the receiver. Even the abrupt changes in signal amplitude do not introduce systematic bias to the retrieval, as long as the SNR is high. The 1 % in-situ refractivity errors at the receiver height could introduce a maximum refractivity retrieval error of 0.5 % (1 K) near the receiver but decreasing gradually to ~0.05% (0.1 K) near the surface. The application of FSI retrieval algorithm on the PRE-Depression Investigation of Cloud-systems in the Tropics (PREDICT) field campaign ARO measurements further confirmed the significant improvement of the ARO refractivity retrievals in the moist lower troposphere comparing with the geometric-optics retrievals. The higher quality ARO measurement inside and near the hurricane could lead to a better understanding of the hurricane genesis and improving the track and intensity of the hurricane prediction.
